Physical Exam: Inspection of the throat and oral cavity
Justification: To assess for any visible lesions, swelling, or abnormalities that may contribute to hoarseness.
To check for any lymphadenopathy or masses that may indicate underlying pathology.

Physical Exam: Laryngeal examination (if possible, using a laryngoscope)
Justification: To directly visualize the vocal cords and assess for any lesions or abnormalities.
To rule out any respiratory issues that may be contributing to the patient's symptoms.
To evaluate for any neurological causes of hoarseness, such as vagus nerve involvement.

Physical Exam: Assessment of voice quality and phonation
Justification: To document the characteristics of the hoarseness and any changes in voice quality.
To ensure the patient is adequately hydrated, as dehydration can exacerbate hoarseness.
To rule out any thoracic issues that may be affecting the larynx or vocal cords.
To address the patient's anxiety, which may impact their overall health and voice use.
